captions.text: [MUSIC]

MATT HUNTER: I got a shoulder
operation done this winter.

And I've been riding on my own
bike quite a bit as I recover

and regain my shoulder
strength.

So I've had some time to plan
some really fun rides.

And I'm really looking forward
to this one for sure.
It's going to be cool.

It's a ride that I've done
before in the south
Chilcotins.

It involves it taking a float
plane from [INAUDIBLE]

Lake and landing on Warner Lake,
and then riding out from
Warner Lake.

On the ride there's a few lakes
I go by so I brought
some fishing equipment.

And hopefully I can
catch my dinner.

I'm going to do it
over two days.

And probably going to be the
first one down the trail this

year so I might run into
a bit of snow.

And this area is just completely
full of wildlife,

so there's a really good chance
of seeing some grizzly

bears and black bears
on the trail.

So I got a bear spray and I'm
going to keep my eyes open.

A ride like this through the
mountains is exactly the kind

of ride I like to do, and take
my time and camp over.

It makes it just that much
more of an adventure.

I'm Matt Hunter, and I'm off
for a couple day ride.
It's going to be great.
[MUSIC]
Oh, these are a tasty treat.

Those are tasty morel
mushrooms.
[WHISTLES]

I'm going to save
those for later.

So I was coming through this
low area and the ground's
pretty soft.

And I looked down as I'm
climbing up right beside my
bike tire, big bear track.
Huge bear that was walking.

I'm pretty happy he was going
the other direction.
But check it out.

The rain just kind of slowed
down just in time, so I'm

going to find a nice spot
here and pull over.

And there is a perfect spot to
stop and do a little fishing.

And that's what going
to do the trick.
[MUSIC]

I just pulled my fish
out of the fire.

And lucked out because they're
cooked perfectly.
And man, are they delicious.

For this trip for my tent
I just brought along
a little sil tarp.

And it's super light
and easy to set up.

It keeps the rain off and
keeps me a bit warmer.

And while I don't think it's
that late, I'm pretty tired.

So I think it's bedtime
for me.

Well, breaking camp
this morning.

Got kind of cold now that
the fire's out.
That's for sure.
So we get on the bike.
Warm up.
[MUSIC]
Look.

Two grizzly bears feeding in
the meadow right there.

The wide angle of the
camera makes them
look pretty far away.

But man, it's always
amazing to see a
grizzly bear in the wild.
[MUSIC]
So there's the valley I rode up
yesterday around that corner.

Kind of as far as you can see
is the lake that I fished.

And kind of beneath that
peak there's my rig
that brought me here.
My [INAUDIBLE]

for me is just the ultimate
trail weapon.
Well, here I am.
Single track.
There's my bike.
And that is the logging road.
So this ride is done.
Sadly, that's a rap.

comments.author: Chris Lenahan

comments.text:
Most bears don't attack, like if your far away and they see you, they 
generally run away (like the bear in the video) I myself have ridden in 
alaska and ran into about 6 grizzly bears who where more curious than 
anything, one was ruffly 4metres away from me smelling the air, then 
hobbled away. Bears aren't killing machines, they're actually quite 
peaceful animals who ONLY defend themselves if provoked,

comments.text: 1:49 y didnt he go under it﻿
comments.author: HecticReflex | Arsenal Reflex | Editing, Music,

comments.text:
He didn't have to cut it but he wanted to to keep the park/trail clean for 
the next guy. Whenever I hike, I always take an extra plastic bag with me 
so I can pick up whatever trash I can get to along the way. Of course I 
don't have to but it's my way to 'contribute' and I'm sure he felt the same 
way.
comments.author: evarona

comments.text:
i mean if everyone just went under it it wouldnt be difficult there is 
plenty of space to stop the the only people that haft to worry about it is 
people that haft to worry about it is people with no brakes.
comments.author: HecticReflex | Arsenal Reflex | Editing, Music,

comments.text: +XTI9 in italy it's often illegal (especially in parks).
comments.author: bigstones84

comments.text:
umm...? Are you lazy? This is called active trail maintenance. Trails need 
maintaining all the time. When you see something that needs taken care of, 
something you can deal with quickly, why would you not deal with it?

Learn to maintain trails, there is no excuse. In this vid Matt Hunter sets 
an example of this.

is beautiful, I wish I could take my bike there!
comments.author: Christophe L

comments.text:
There's a local bumper sticker that says "My life is better than your 
vacation.  Bend, OR."  It's true, the single track here is world class and 
luckily we have literally hundreds of miles of it!
comments.author: Jeffery Marsh

comments.text: True erikk
comments.author: Nick Greenen

comments.text:
I live in Bend, OR and find myself MTB riding 50-100 miles per week; my 
comment doesn't connote worry, but rather, suggests people might try to see 
with eyes that see....

If you ever get a chance, visit Bend and enjoy our 800 miles of amazing 
landscape and MTB single-track. Take care!
comments.author: Jeffery Marsh

Dear sir you really inspired me with your excellent and exciting trail

and life! Charl (Sweden)
